quiz.title: Calculus Limits Quiz 2
quiz.subtitle: Intermediate Value Theorem — Advanced Applications (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Calculus

questions.question: If f is continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0 and f(1)=1, and g is continuous on [0,1] with g(0)=1 and g(1)=0, prove that f(x)=g(x) for some x in [0,1]. Which function should we apply IVT to?
questions.explanation: h(0)=f(0)-g(0)=0-1=-1<0, h(1)=f(1)-g(1)=1-0=1>0. Since h is continuous, IVT guarantees h(c)=0 for some c, meaning f(c)=g(c).

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,2] satisfies f(0)=3 and f(2)=1. Which value is NOT guaranteed by IVT?
questions.explanation: IVT guarantees all values between f(2)=1 and f(0)=3. 0 is not between 1 and 3.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [a,b] and takes only rational values, then f must be:
questions.explanation: By IVT, if f takes two distinct values, it must take all real values between them (including irrationals). So if f takes only rational values, it cannot take two distinct values.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=f(1). For any natural number n, there exists c in [0,1-1/n] such that f(c)=f(c+1/n). Which theorem proves this?
questions.explanation: g(0)=f(0)-f(1/n), g(1-1/n)=f(1-1/n)-f(1). If these have opposite signs, IVT gives g(c)=0. If same sign, consider intermediate points.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [-1,1] satisfies f(-1)=-2, f(0)=1, f(1)=0. How many roots does f have in (-1,1)?
questions.explanation: f(-1)=-2<0, f(0)=1>0 → root in (-1,0). f(0)=1>0, f(1)=0 → root at x=1 or in (0,1). So at least 2 roots counting multiplicity.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [0,2] and f(0)=f(2), then the equation f(x)=f(x+1) has a solution in:
questions.explanation: Consider g(x)=f(x)-f(x+1) on [0,1]. g(0)=f(0)-f(1), g(1)=f(1)-f(2)=f(1)-f(0). So g(0)=-g(1). If g(0)=0, done. Else, opposite signs → IVT gives g(c)=0.

questions.question: A continuous function on [0,4] takes each value in its range exactly twice. What is the maximum number of roots it can have?
questions.explanation: If it takes each value twice, it must be non-monotonic. Maximum roots occur with symmetric oscillation: can have roots at 1,2,3 (three distinct roots) but careful: if it takes 0 twice, that means 2 roots maximum for that value.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [a,b] and let g(x)=max{f(t): a≤t≤x}. Which is true about g?
questions.explanation: The maximum function of a continuous function is continuous (though not necessarily differentiable). All continuous functions satisfy IVT.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [0,1] and 0≤f(x)≤1 for all x, then f has a fixed point (f(c)=c). This is proved by:
questions.explanation: g(0)=f(0)-0≥0, g(1)=f(1)-1≤0. If either is 0, done. Else, opposite signs → IVT gives g(c)=0, so f(c)=c.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,2π] satisfies f(0)=f(2π). How many solutions does f(x)=f(x+π) have?
questions.explanation: Consider g(x)=f(x)-f(x+π) on [0,π]. g(0)=f(0)-f(π), g(π)=f(π)-f(2π)=f(π)-f(0). So g(0)=-g(π). If g(0)=0, then x=0 and x=π are solutions. Else, IVT gives one in (0,π), and by periodicity/symmetry, at least one more.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [a,b] and f(x) is never 0, then f(x) must be:
questions.explanation: If f takes both positive and negative values, by IVT it would have to take 0. So f must maintain the same sign.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0, f(1)=1. For any y in (0,1), there exists c in (0,1) with f(c)=y. This statement is:
options: True only if f is increasing
True only if f is one-to-one
questions.explanation: This is exactly the Intermediate Value Theorem: continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0, f(1)=1 guarantees all intermediate values.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,2] satisfies f(0)=1, f(1)=3, f(2)=2. Which value is guaranteed to be in the range?
questions.explanation: IVT on [0,1]: all values between 1 and 3. IVT on [1,2]: all values between 3 and 2 (i.e., between 2 and 3). So 2.5 is guaranteed, but 0 and 4 are not.

questions.question: If f and g are continuous on [a,b] and f(a)<g(a), f(b)>g(b), then:
questions.explanation: Apply IVT to h(x)=f(x)-g(x). h(a)<0, h(b)>0, so h(c)=0 for some c, meaning f(c)=g(c).

questions.question: A continuous function on [0,4] has f(0)=1, f(1)=4, f(2)=2, f(3)=5, f(4)=3. The equation f(x)=3 has:
questions.explanation: f(2)=2<3, f(3)=5>3 → solution in (2,3). f(3)=5>3, f(4)=3 → solution at x=4. So at least 2 solutions.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [a,b] and f(x) is irrational for all x, then f must be:
questions.explanation: If f takes two distinct irrational values, by IVT it would take all real values between them (including rationals). So f cannot take two distinct values.

questions.question: Let f be continuous on [0,1] with f(0)=0. If ∫₀¹ f(x)dx > 0, then:
questions.explanation: If f(x)≤0 for all x, then ∫₀¹ f(x)dx ≤ 0. Contrapositive: if integral > 0, then f(x)>0 for some x.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [-1,1] satisfies f(-1)=-1, f(0)=1, f(1)=-1. The minimum number of local extrema is:
questions.explanation: From -1 to 0: increases from -1 to 1 (local max at or before 0). From 0 to 1: decreases from 1 to -1 (local min at or after 0). So at least 2 extrema.

questions.question: If f is continuous on [0,2] and f(0)+f(1)+f(2)=3, then:
questions.explanation: If all f(x)>1, then sum>3. If all f(x)<1, then sum<3. So by continuity and IVT, f must take value 1 somewhere.

questions.question: A continuous function f on [0,3] has f(0)=0, f(1)=2, f(2)=1, f(3)=3. The range of f contains:
questions.explanation: On [0,1]: covers [0,2]. On [1,2]: covers between 2 and 1 (i.e., [1,2]). On [2,3]: covers [1,3]. Combined: covers [0,3].
